history.value: The hive-mind Bubbles encircle their adversaries, exploding with chromatic displays with one bursting Bubble causing others to burst in turn. Their overwhelming numbers and overwhelming force tend to... well, overwhelm.

wildBody.value: As a main player or ally, you may play an attack card as a reinforcement if it has the same value as an attack card revealed by either main player.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Pop.
As a main player or ally, before encounter cards are selected, you

this power by announcing, "Let's pop!" or by making two pop sound effects. Then, instead of selecting an encounter card, the main player on your side may select a reinforcement card. If a reinforcement card is revealed, it is instead treated as an attack card equal to its value, and each player on your side may play one attack card from their hand as a reinforcement card. (Players can play additional reinforcement cards normally.)

powerName.value: You have the power to Pop.

superBody.value: you may play this flare. If
the main player on your side does not select a reinforcement card, each ally (on both sides) can play an encounter card as a reinforcement card on their side.

history.value: The vastness of the Cosmos forces them to operate at the very edge of reality, barely perceiving the life around them as they modify the fabric of the universe to suit their needs. The ever-increasing chaos and anarchy they create requires that they continue to revise and revisit what they have sown.

body.value: At the start of your turn, you may draw a card from the deck or discard a card from your hand (before determining if you must draw a new hand).
During your regroup phase, you may redistribute any number of your ships on your colonies among your colonies
When you draw your own color for destiny, you may treat it as a wild destiny.
After the hyperspace gate is aimed at one of your home planets, you may re-aim the gate at any other planet in your system where the offense does not have a foreign colony.

After alliances are formed, if you are not a main player or ally, you may ally with either main player by sending more ships into the encounter (without exceeding your ship limit) than the player has in the encounter.

During the planning phase, after cards are selected, you may forced any selected negotiate cards to be flipped faceup. If your opponent did not select a negotiate, you may swap your selected card with another card from your hand.

As a main player, after cards are revealed, if you revealed a negotiate, you may send one of your ships in the encounter to the warp to discard that negotiate and replace it with an attack card from your hand.
As a main player, after you win the encounter, you may gain one reward. This occurs after compensation is collected, if any.

wildBody.value: At the start of another player's turn, you may demand anything that that player can give you in a deal. If they refuse, for the rest of the encounter, you may zap their alien powers. At the end of the encounter, give this card to the Cosmos
or discard it if the Cosmos

powerBody.value: You have the power of Rules.
If you are not the offense, after the offense wins the encounter, you
this power. Look through your essence card

, choose one rule, and play it faceup next to this sheet. Instead of playing a rule, you may choose to discard a rule already in play.

The abilities on rules are available to all players. After another player uses one of your rules, you gain one reward.

powerName.value: You have the power of Rules.

superBody.value: After you use one of your rules,

history.value: The Decoys have learned the hard way to have backups and plans B, C, and even D. They hate to not have enough resources to win battles, but hate even more to expend too many. If an adversary is distracted by bright lights, silly sounds, or impressive hats, it only servers the Decoy's elbaorate plans.

wildBody.value: As a main player, if your opponent agrees, you may replace an attack card revealed by either of you with a negotiate card from your hand.

powerBody.value: You have the power of Contingency.
As a main player, before encounter cards are selected, you

this power to play an encounter card faceup on this sheet. During the reveal phase, after you reveal your normal encounter card, you may choose to swap your encounter card with the card on this sheet. After the encounter, your opponent decides what to do with the card on this sheet: they may take it, discard it, or force you to take it.

powerName.value: You have the power of Contingency.

superBody.value: You may use your power as an ally. The main player on your side chooses whether or not to swap their card.

history.value: Long accustomed to sharing power in their small city-states, the Delegators have learned keen sensitivity to group dynamics. From a subtle twitch to an emphatic gaze they can recognize leaders among their allies, while the slightest quiver oft betrays the weak among their enemies.

wildBody.value: choose a non-main player that has a colony on the targeted planet. The chosen player becomes the defense
(Your ships on that planet are now bystanders)

powerBody.value: You have the power to Delegate.
As a main player or ally, after alliances are formed, you

this power to choose an offensive ally to become the offense and/or a defensive ally to become the defense. Displaced main players become allies on the side they are on. If the original offense was displaced and the new offense wins or makes a deal, the encounter is treated as successful for the original offense. After the outcome is determined, play returns to the original offense or passes to the next player, as appropriate.

powerName.value: You have the power to Delegate.

superBody.value: When using your power, you may delegate a player not involved in the encounter to be a main player

history.value: The overpowering rage of the once comely Dragons gradually misshaped them into their current form. Having turned their backs on all intelligent discourse with others, they now seek only to incinerate their enemies, and revel in the glory of the suffering of the weak.

wildBody.value: As the offense, you may send one of the defense's ships on the targeted planet to the warp.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Scorch.
After destiny is drawn, if it matches a player color or is wild, add that card to this sheet. After the third card of the same color is placed on this sheet,

this power to discard all three destiny cards, and then "scorch" a planet in that player's home system. All ships on that planet are sent to the warp and the planet is removed from the game. After a destiny card is placed on this sheet, you may treat each wild destiny here as any color.

As the offense, instead of drawing destiny, you may choose to discard a destiny card from this sheet to have the encounter as though you had drawn that card

If the destiny deck needs to be reshuffled, remove all destiny cards from this sheet and shuffle them into the destiny deck.

powerName.value: You have the power to Scorch.

superBody.value: You may use your power when a second destiny card of a player's color is placed on your sheet. You cannot use wild destiny cards for this effect.

history.value: The elite forces of the Extractors have dedicated themselves to rescuing the displaced. Sometimes they feel the need to save others - even from themselves - and won't hestitate to act.

wildBody.value: When another player collects compensation, after they have taken the card(s) but before they add them to their hand,
add this card to those cards, and shuffle them. Draw two of them at random, and return any remaining cards to that player.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Extract.
As the offense or offensive ally, if your side wins the encounter, before landing you

this power. Move all ships belonging to another player (even bystanders) from the targetted planet to one other planet before those ships would be lost or captured. If you move the ships to a planet where that player gains a foreign colony, gain two rewards for each ship you moved. If you move the ships to a planet in that player's home system where they do not have a colony, draw two cards at random from their hand.

powerName.value: You have the power to Extract.

superBody.value: When using your power, you may extract two players' ships from the targeted planet, sending them to the same planet.

history.value: At first glance, a Force appears to be yet another mystical entity, but nothing could be further from the truth as their tomfoolery and hijinks lead them to ridiculous, improbably situations. From their questionable "Two-Card Monte" to their dubious "Truth Simulator," who knows what they'll get up to next.

wildBody.value: During launch, you may give a card to a main player. If that card is played or revealed during this encounter, you and that player each gain two rewards. Otherwise, you must send one of your ships to the warp.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Interlope.
If you are not a main player or ally, after encounter cards are selected and before they are revealed, you

this power to choose a main player. Look at the chosen player's encounter card. You may swap that card with one from your hand (that player may look at the swapped card). If you swapped cards and that player wins the encounter or makes a deal, gain three rewards. If that player loses the encounter or fails to make a deal, send two of your ships from your colonies to the warp, and that player gains one reward.

powerName.value: You have the power to Interlope.

superBody.value: You may use your power as an ally.

history.value: Taking their love of the Cosmos to an uncool degree, the physically unremarkable Geeks huddle together in the safety of their interests. They have studies the nuances of every known alien species, desperate to find weakness, desperate to perhaps be more like them, but mostly just desperate.

wildBody.value: If another player would win the game,
say aloud the name of a card that would change the outcome. If any player has it, they give it to you. Otherwise, you have 30 seconds to find it. If you are given or find the card, play it.

powerBody.value: You have the power of Esoterica.
As a main player, after the defense is determined,

this power to force your opponent to secretly draw a random unused alien. If they drew an alien with Game Setup text, or one that is not allowed in the game, they remove that alien from the game and draw again. Then, that player reads aloud its short power description (the upside-down text at the top of the sheet). If you correctly guess the alien's name in one attempt, you either gain the sheet under your control as your "buddy" or discard it. If your guess is incorrect, your opponent chooses to either give it to you as your buddy, or discard it.

You use the power of your buddy in addition to your own power. Before you would gain a second buddy, remove your current buddy from the game.

powerName.value: You have the power of Esoterica.

superBody.value: play this card to keep up to five buddies at one time. If you lose this card, choose one buddy to keep and remove the rest.

history.value: Gremlins can never leave well-enough alone. They exist in a culture that rewards interference, trespassing, and insubordination. While other aliens may attempt to live in peace, the Gremlins remind them that trouble is always brewing.

wildBody.value: After your color is drawn from destiny, if you are not the offense,
force the offense to discard their hand, draw a new one, and continue their turn.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Meddle.

At the start of each player's turn, draw a hazard card from the hazard deck (even if the Hazard Deck variant is not being used) and place it facedown on this sheet.

At the end of the destiny phase, if no hazard warnings were drawn during this encounter, you
this power to play a hazard card from this sheet. Before the hazard deck discard pile is shuffled to reform the hazard deck, discard all hazard cards on this sheet.

powerName.value: You have the power to Meddle.

superBody.value: As the offense, if a hazard warning was drawn,
draw a hazard card and place it on your sheet. Then, you can use your power (even though a hazard warning was drawn).

short.value: Ships Are Worth More as Ally

history.value: Selfless guards, the Guardians are dedicated to the preservation of those they serve. Leaving their own interests unguarded, the Guardians put every effort into the victory of their allies. Perhaps they are mindless thugs, as their detractors describe them. Yet, it is hard to claim and their lack of a brain is preventing them from crafting a cunning plan.

wildBody.value: increase the value of the attack card revealed by the main player on your side by 4.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Guard.
As an ally, after encounter cards are revealed,

this power to change the value of your ships for encounter totals. Each of your ships is worth the number of ships that the main player on your side has in the encounter. For example, if the main player on your side has three ships in the encounter, each of your ships is worth three for encounter totals.

powerName.value: You have the power to Guard.

superBody.value: you may play this flare. Each
of your ships is worth thrice the number of allies on your side. For example, if you had three allies, each of your ships is worth nine for encounter totals.

history.value: When ships are in short supply, the enterprising Hurtz are happy to help with a handy off-planet stash. "We put you in the pilot's seat." For a modest fee, of course.

wildBody.value: to lease your alien power to another player for the remainder of the encounter. If they agree, they can use your power instead of their own and you cannot use your own power (or their power). If that player is on the winning side, take two cards at random from that player. Otherwise, take only one card.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Lease.
Either before or after encounter cards are revealed (but not both), you

this power to make an "offer to lease" your ships to each player in the encounter. For each player that agrees (heretofore the "lessee"), take a number of your ships from any of your colonies not involved in the encounter up to the number of ships that the lessee had in the encounter and stackthose ships under the lessee's ships. Then, place one token on this sheet, or two if the lease is made after encounter cards are revealed.

A lessee's ships are treated as their own ships and are worth two for encounter totals and rewards. However, leased ships cannot move unless they move with an equal number of non-leased ships from the same stack. If leased ships no longer have a non-leased ship above them, or if the lessee no longer controls the leased ships for any reason, they return to your colonies (regardless of other game effects).

Once per encounter, at any time, you may discard a token from their sheet to either cancel the lease on all leased ships for one lessee (returning them to your colonies) or to double the number of rewards you gain as a successful defensive ally.

powerName.value: You have the power to Lease.

superBody.value: gain three tokens (instead of one or two).

history.value: Expelled from the fiery depths of a red giant star, the Inferno defiled the cold wastes of space. They sought out other sources of heat to burn, increasing their power with each flare up. Nothing will satisfy the Inferno until the entire Cosmos is consumed in an ultimate conflagration.

wildBody.value: As a main player or ally,
you may play this flare. Each
player on your side may discard a flare from their hand. The first discarded flare adds 20 to your side's total and each flare after that adds 10. If at least one player discarded a flare, give this
or discard it if the Inferno is not playing

gameSetup.value: Shuffle the additional five copies of the Inferno flare into the cosmic deck after hands are dealt.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Flare.
After another player plays a flare and attempts to return it to their hand, you

this power to take it instead.

When you have no encounter cards and would discard your hand to draw a new one, reveal any flares in your hand, and set them aside. Draw your new hand, and then add the set-aside flares to your hand.

powerName.value: You have the power to Flare.

superBody.value: Return this card to your hand. Then
you have five flares in your hand, two of which are Inferno flares

history.value: The short-lived Insects rapidly adapt to match the strengths of any opponent. They believe that their ability to metamorphose and copy any ecological innovation will lead to ultimate control of the Cosmos.

wildBody.value: As a main player, after you lose an encounter,
discard your hand and draw a new one. (Return this card to your hand.)

powerBody.value: You have the power of Metamorphosis.
After a player plays and resolves a flare, you

this power to either discard a flare from your hand of an alien not in game or, if you have no such flares in your hand, draw and discard a flare from the unused flare deck. If that alien does not have Game Setup text and is allowed in the game, gain their sheet under your control as "new flesh."

You use the power of your new flesh in addition to your own power. Before you would gain new flesh, remove your older flesh from the game.

powerName.value: You have the power of Metamorphosis.

superBody.value: When you use your power, you
draw and discard a flare from the unused flare deck even if you have a flare in your hand.

short.value: Gains Colonies From Ships in the Warp

history.value: The small, odd-looking Lemmings are known for their mass migrations, especially those resulting in self-sacrifice. What is not well known about the Lemmings is their unusual ability to turn up in unexpected places, seemingly out of nowhere. The connection between these points is not well understood, noot even by scholars.

wildBody.value: During your regroup phase, when you retrieve a ship from the warp, you may place it on any planet where all players have a colony except for you and the planet's owner.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Migrate.
After the defense is determined, if you have nine or more ships in the warp, you
this power to move four of your ships out of the warp onto any planet in the defense's system where you do not have a foreign colony.

powerName.value: You have the power to Migrate.

superBody.value: When you use your power, you
move one to three ships from the warp (instead of four).

history.value: The Lloyd have been known to generations as protectors. Although they should have learned their lesson by trusting
Nobody
nobody
, the Lloyd still always uphold any contract.

wildBody.value: When you would lose a colony,
one of the ships that would have been lost or captured

powerBody.value: You have the power to Insure.

this power to "offer to insure" any or all of the following assets of another player until the end of the encounter: alien powers (before they are used), ships (before they are lost or captured), and specifically named cards (before they are played, discarded or taken). Insured cards must be named explicitly (e.g. attack 30, Cosmic Zap)
and be in the insured player's hand

. If your offer is accepted, place a token on this sheet.

Insured alien powers cannot be lost or cancelled. Insured ships are returned to colonies instead of being lost or captured. Insured cards cannot be forcibly discarded, taken, or collected as compensation. An insured card cannot be played more than once in the encounter.

At any time, you may spend a token to gain a reward.

powerName.value: You have the power to Insure.

superBody.value: Once per encounter, if a player of your choice agrees to it, you may use your power to insure one card in your hand or your ships in the encounter. That player may gain one reward for agreeing.

history.value: Originating on a highly ferrous planetoid, the Magnets thrived on the intense fields generated at its poles. Soon they achieved the ability to manipulate and reverse energy fields by group induction, and are now attempting to use their magnetic personalities to attract (and repel) all they meet.

wildBody.value: As a main player, before cards are selected,
. Your opponent cannot select that card unless they have no other encounter cards

powerBody.value: You have the power to Attract or Repel.
ally, after alliances are formed, you

this power to force one offensive ally to become a defensive ally, or vice versa. You cannot use this power to choose yourself.

As a main player or ally, after alliances are formed, if you did not use the previous power, you
this power to force one player in the encounter to match the same number of ships that you have in the encounter by moving ships to or from their colonies, as appropriate.

powerName.value: You have the power to Attract or Repel.

history.value: The Null and Void were worshiped are the twin gods of the Negators. Whenever another being attempts a positive action, Negators are compelled to counteract it and deny its existence. Experiencing kinship with all that is negative and disdain for all that is not negative, the apathy and generally undefined attitude of the Null became their undoing when the Negators and the Hate joined forces to subtract their former idols from the Cosmos.

body.value: After an artifact, flare, or reinforcement card is played, return it to its owner's hand. That specific card cannot be played again during this encounter.
After an encounter card is selected but before it is revealed, return it to its owner's hand. That player must select another card, if able.
After a player aims the hyperspace gate or uses an effect that targets a specific planet, that player must choose another valid planet, if able.

After ships on a specific location (planet, tech card, etc.) are chosen for any reason, the player must choose ships from another valid location and the number of ships must be different, if possible.
When a player would accept an invitation to become an ally, they cannot ally with that side. (They may still become an ally with the other side if they were invited.)

After the offense draws a wild destiny and chooses a player, they must chose another player. Or, after the offense draws a destiny of their color, they must choose option A unless there is no player to encounter in their home system.
After a main player uses an optional power or uses an ability that requires them to be a main player, cancel that power or ability.
After an ally uses an optional power or uses an ability that requires them to be an ally, cancel that power or ability.

wildBody.value: If you are a main player, after cards are revealed,
all revealed attack cards with a positive value
have a negative value instead (e.g., a 10 becomes a -10). Then, give this card to the Negator or discard it if the Negator is not playing.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Negate.
this power to play a negation from your essence card cache on another player as per the timing on the negation.

powerName.value: You have the power to Negate.

superBody.value: You may use your power twice per encounter.

history.value: The origin of the Phantoms remains a mystery, but all that could be said of their first appearance was: "Alas, poor Spheric. They fell victim to the night." The Phantoms' motives and social structure are unclear, but people come out in droves to witness them.

wildBody.value: As a main player, after encounter cards are revealed,
place up to four ships from your colonies on either the hyperspace gate or the targeted planet, as appropriate. (This can cause you to be above your normal limit.)

gameSetup.value: Place one ship from each of your planets on this sheet.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Materialize.
As a main player, after cards are revealed,

this power to add two to your encounter total for each of your ships on this sheet. Your ships in this encounter do not add to your encounter total but do count for compensation and rewards normally.

When your ships would return to colonies, you may place one or more of them on this sheet instead. When you would move ships from your colonies or choose ships for other effects, you may use ships from this sheet. If this sheet is lost or turned facedown, ships on it are returned to your colonies.

powerName.value: You have the power to Materialize.

superBody.value: use your power as an ally

history.value: The antediluvian Silencers long dwelt in a state of pure meditation. Aghasty at the chaotic proliferation of verbose - some grandiloquent, other time garrulous - life forms, they feel a holy duty to bring the virtue of quietude back to the Cosmos.

wildBody.value: cancel the use of your opponent's power. This is not treated as a cosmic zap. Your opponent's power cannot be used for the rest of the encounter. Then, give this card to the Silencer or discard it if the Silencer is not in the game.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Silence.
As a main player, after destiny is drawn, you

this power to place one silence token, total silence side faceup, on the sheet of any player who does not have a silence token. When a player with a silence token speaks, invites allies, accepts alliances, or uses optional powers, they are penalized for being "too noisy." Penalize them either by sending any one of their ships not in the encounter to the warp or by forcing them to discard a card at random from their hand.

If a player has a total silence token, at the end of the encounter, they flip it to its partial silence side. If a player has a partial silence token, after they are penalized, they return that token to your supply.

powerName.value: You have the power to Silence.

superBody.value: flip one or two partial silence tokens to the total silence side.

history.value: Swirling masses of flexible appendages, filaments, and processes, the uncanny Tentacles always seem to reach into every corner of the Cosmos. Just when you think you have a handle on them, the Tentacles have another sucker-bearing tendril up their proverbial sleeves, ready to envelop, engulf, or merely obfuscate.

wildBody.value: When you would gain rewards or collected compensation,
discard a reinforcement to gain or collect its value in additional rewards or compensation, as appropriate.

powerBody.value: You have the power of Appendages.
As a main player or ally, after encounter cards are revealed,
this power. Choose one revealed encounter card that has a numerical value (including a morph). Add each of the value's digits to
side's total. For example, if you reveal an attack 15, add 1 and 5 to
the card's value for a total of 21.
your side's total in addition to the card and ships on your side

powerName.value: You have the power of Appendages.

superBody.value: add the digits of both revealed encounter cards to one side's encounter total (instead of just one of the encounter cards).

history.value: Brainwashed by centuries of being told how they would inherit all they survey, the Meek have tirelessly adhered to a strict practice of submission, compliance, and gentleness. If all goes to prophecy, their ultimate gain will be well worth the suffering.

wildBody.value: collect compensation from the opposing main player.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Yield.
As a main player, when you lose the encounter
establish a foreign colony in the opponent's home system with up to 4 ships from any of your colonies
Failing to make a deal is not treated as a loss.

after you establish any foreign colonies (but before you would win the game),
move your colony marker back. Your colony marker cannot go below zero
return all of your ships on one of your foreign colonies to your other colonies
Making a successful deal is not treated as a win.

powerName.value: You have the power to Yield.

history.value: Ever reminiscing about the "good old times," the Throwback prefer things to work as they once did. Although they romanticize the past as unquestionably superior, they nonetheless also exploit the blessings of modern life. This apparent cognitive dissonance gives way to caprice as the throwback choose to live in the past or the present, as befits the need of the moment.

wildBody.value: You may Un-Zap any Zap. Cancel the effect of any Cosmic Zap or Card Zap, a Flarezap (if you can find one), or any other "Zap" effect from an Edict (which you probably call an Artifact). Then discard this Flare, although the real Throwback can immediately snatch it from the discard pile. This Wild Flare cannot be Zapped.

powerBody.value: You have the power of anarchronism.

Whenever you draw a hand, including your starting hand, draw seven cards instead of eight.

When speaking, you should refer to colonies as bases, ships as tokens, encounters as challenges, encounter cards as challenge cards, artifacts as edicts, negotiate cards as compromise cards, compensation as consolation, and the hyperspace gate as the cone. When other players use the modern terms, you

this power to receive one reward when you correct another player in this way.

At any time, you

this power to purge from your hand one or more modern cards having: a card type other than Attack, Compromise (Negotiate), Flare, Edict (Artifact), or kicker; a cardback not matching the cosmic deck; or an Attack value other than 01, 04-10, 12-18, 20, 30 or 40. You may discard them and draw an equal number of cards; give these cards to another player; or trade these cards to other players (if willing) for anything they could give you as part of a deal.

You may play any number of flares per challenge, even playing the same flare more than once if the context for playing it comes up more than once.

powerName.value: You have the power of anarchronism.

superBody.value: Any time before the outcome of a challenge is final, you may declare that challenge to be "retro." All reinforcement cards played are worth zero, and any main player who revealed a Morph immediately loses the challenge.

history.value: The mutagenic conditions of the Vector solar system wrecked havoc on their communication capabilities, and as a result they have a reputation for confounding the expectations of their allies. The Vectors make their own demands when committing to alliances of convenience - taking resources when attacking, and demanding colonial presence when defending.

powerBody.value: You have the power of Direction.
After you accept an invitation to become an ally,

this power to choose which side your vector token is faceup: either its normal or its reverse side. If the reverse side is faceup and your side of the encounter wins, you gain the effect of winning as though you had been on the other side of the encounter (i.e., landing on the planet if allied with the defense or receiving rewards if allied with the offense). If the normal side is faceup and your side of the encounter wins, you gain the normal effects of winning. This power overrides other effects that change what happens if you win.

powerName.value: You have the power of Direction.

history.value: The Witches so concentrated their anger about life's injustices that their inner rage became a force they could project against others. Now they never seem quite as happy as when an ill turn of fate releases this power and they can curse their enemies.

body.value: You cannot become an ally or invite allies.
Discard all artifacts in your hand. If you gain an artifact, you must discard it immediately.
Discard all flares in your hand. If you gain a flare, you must discard it immediately.
As a main player, before encounter cards are selected, you must reveal the attack card in your hand that has the highest value to all players.
You cannot win the game.
As a main player, ships on your side subtract from your encounter total (instead of adding).
You annot play any non-encounter cards from your hand.

wildBody.value: use your power even if you have fewer than the required number of home colonies.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Curse.
As a main player or ally, after you lose an encounter,

this power to "curse" one or more opposing players. For each player, choose a curse from your essence card cache and place it faceup in from of them. You cannot curse a player who is already cursed.

During each regroup phase, each cursed player may place one of their ships from their colonies onto their curse card. After a curse card has a number of ships on it equal to the number on the card, all of those ships are sent to the warp and the curse is placed in your unavailable pile.

powerName.value: You have the power to Curse.

superBody.value: use your power on cursed players. When you do, place the player's previous curse in your unavailable pile and send any ships on it to the warp.

history.value: Sadistic to a degree unparalleled in recorded annals, the miserable Wracks haven't a decent sharn in their claydorns. After generations of bullying local flora and fauna, they now dream of intimidating the universe.

wildBody.value: As a main player, for the rest of the encounter,
send one of their ships from any of their colonies to the warp each time they use their power.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Injure.
As a main player or ally, after a player on the opposing side plays a card,
this power. That player must send one of their ships from any of their colonies to the warp.

powerName.value: You have the power to Injure.

superBody.value: As a main player, after alliances are formed,

offer your opponent a deal. If it is accepted, proceed to resolution. If it is rejected, send one of their ships on a colony to the warp and you may offer additional deals; you may offer a number of deals up to the number of ships you have in the encounter. If they reject all of your deals, the encounter ends as a loss for your side.

short.value: Wins by Helping Another Player Win

history.value: The Zilch have no history, as they exist outside of our concepts of time. For them, past, present, and future are the same.

body.value: Cancel one use of another alien's power. That power may not be used again during this encounter.
Before another player uses their alien power, prevent it from being canceled by any effect for the rest of the encounter.

Look at one of the following: a player's hand, any facedown cards on an alien sheet, the top five cards of a deck, a token, an essence cache, or a selected encounter card. Then, you may speak privately (or publically) with one or more players.
As an ally, after encounter cards are selected but before they are revealed, return your ships from the encounter to your colonies. You may force another ally on either side to do the same.
Give a non-encounter card from your hand to another player.
When you would gain rewards, you may choose anohter player to gain some or all of them instead.
Take a card at random from another player's hand. After looking at it, give it to a player other than yourself.

wildBody.value: If another player has fewer foreign colonies than each of the other players,
establish a colony on any planet. Then, give this card to the Zilch or discard it if the Zilch is not in the game.

gameSetup.value: Secretly choose a destiny card that matches a player color and does not have a hazard warning. Place it facedown on this sheet. That player is "ordained".

powerBody.value: You have the power of Zilch.

this power to play a fate from your essence card cache.

If the ordained player wins the game alone, you win the game with them. If the ordained player would be part of a shared win that does not include you, you win by yourself instead.

You may still win the game via the normal method.

powerName.value: You have the power of Zilch.

history.value: What the brutes lack in hostility, they make up for in immensity. They tend to gardens with blunt, careful hands where they can use their strength and massive frames to displace any soils in their way. Although other aliens often feel coerced after interacting with the Brutes, this usually stems from floriographic miscommunication rather than actual mallice.

wildBody.value: As a main player or ally, before compensation or rewards are gained, you may reduce each player's compensation and rewards to one.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Pressure.
As an ally, after alliances are formed, you

this power to pressure one player on the opposing side. That player must either remove all of their ships from the encounter and return them to their colonies or allow you to look at a number of random cards in their hand up to the number of ships that they had in the encounter and take one card of your choice.

If all of a main player's ships are removed, they continue the encounter with zero ships. If all of an ally's ships are removed, they are no longer an ally.

powerName.value: You have the power to Pressure.

superBody.value: You may use your power as a main player

short.value: Plays with Fire to Gain Rewards

history.value: Preferring an unpredictable and exhilaratng existence to certainty, Daredevils are addicted to adrenaline. Risk augments the Daredevil's abilities, and their allies either ramp up or blow up. For Daredevils, the closer the shave, the bigger rush - and they have the scars to prove it.

wildBody.value: ally, after encounter cards are selected but before they are revealed, you may play this card. If your side wins by 4 or less, use one of your ships in the encounter to establish a colony in the opposing main player's system. Otherwise, lose three ships in the warp.

powerBody.value: You have the power of Peril.
As a main player or ally, after encounter cards have been revealed, you

this power to discard one attack card from your hand. Substract its value from your side's total.

As a main player or ally, after your side wins the encounter by 5 or less, each player on your side receives rewards equal to the number of ships they have in the encounter (in addition to any other benefits receives for winning).

powerName.value: You have the power of Peril.

history.value: The opportunistic Demons seek to sap the will to win out of any whom they encounter. The molten homeworlds of their original galaxy will be reclaimed in the name of vengance.

wildBody.value: When a player is about to take compensation from another player, you may force that player to take compensation from you instead, and then you take compensation from the original targeted player.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Dominate.
If you are not a main player or ally, after encounter cards are selected but before they are revealed, you

this power to discard an attack card from your hand. After encounter cards are revealed, if your card is lower than both revealed attack cards, each main player sends one of your ships to the warp from any of your colonies. If your card is higher than a main player's attack card, you may "dominate" ships
. After the outcome is determined, you may take up to four of your ships from one of your colonies and use them to replace any of those
, except those on the targetted planet,

on a one-for-one basis before those ships land on the planet or their owners gain rewards. Dominated ships are captured and placed on this sheet. Then, the encounter is completed normally.

After you draw a new hand, send all ships on this sheet to the warp and gain one reward for each player whose ships were on this sheet.

powerName.value: You have the power to Dominate.

history.value: A Grumpus is indeed a ponderous sourpuss. Most species prefer not to engage with the Grumpi, lest they be suckered into a loquacious haranguing about how the Cosmos was better back in their millennium. But be careful what you do while visiting a Grumpus home world; they cannot stand it when their visitors pay to much attention to their communication devices.

wildBody.value: After the hyperspace gate is aimed,
send one ship from the targeted system to the warp.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Grrr-ump.
As a main player, after you lose the encounter or fail to make a deal,

this power. Each player with a colony in your system must send one of their ships from your system to the warp (even if they just established that colony). If this causes a player to lose a colony you may establish a foreign colony on any planet in that player's home system.

You do not lose your power because of having too few home colonies.

powerName.value: You have the power to Grrr-ump.

superBody.value: send two ships to the warp (instead of one).

history.value: Every 170 years, Locusts pour out of parallel universes in massive swarms of ships, seeking out planets that they can completely ingest to meet the ever-growing energy needs of their people.

wildBody.value: At the start of the regroup phase, you may send four of your ships from your colonies to the warp to destroy a planet that is not in the Locust's home system, remove it from the game. Any ships on that planet are sent to the warp. Then, give this flare to the Locust or discard it if the Locust is not playing.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Consume.
As the offense or an offensive ally, after you win the encounter, if the targeted planet has no ships on it other than the defense's ships,

this power to consume the planet. Remove the consumed planet from the game, place it on this sheet, and send all ships on the planet to the warp. Each of your allies may either land their ships on another planet of their choice in the targeted system or return those ships to their colonies. Your ships return to your colonies.

Each planet you have consumed counts as one foreign colony towards victory for you, even if this power is later lost or stolen. If this power is stolen, consumed planets do not transfer with it.

powerName.value: You have the power to Consume.

history.value: The Masochists derive pleasure from experiences that others would describe as pain. However, some alien species suspect it's really a religious ritual to bring forth the Masochist's dominance in this universe.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Love Pain.

this power to win the game if you have lost all of your ships. Lost ships include those in the warp, those removed from the game, and those captured by other players. Your ships cannot be removed from the warp or prevented from going to the warp for any reason during the game.

You do not lose this power because of having too few home colonies, and you may still win the game via the normal

powerName.value: You have the power to Love Pain.

history.value: Starting life on a diminutive planet, the Microns imagined themselves to be enormous beings compared to their local flora and fauna. Undaunted by discovering that they were much smaller than galactic standards, this has not impeded their desire for universal dominance. The Microns fill their vessels with countless souls to overwhelm any planet they happen upon.

send a number of ships up to the number of your home and foreign colonies.

this power. Each of your ships is worth two for encounter totals, compenstatio, and rewards for the remainder of the encounter.

powerName.value: You have the power of Mass Numbers.

history.value: Generations of research has led to a 99.8% rejection of inferior goods. With a chortle and a flick, the Perfectionists now swipe their way to mastery of all things Cosmic, keeping only the best for themselves and consigning the worst to the rest.

wildBody.value: After you gain a card as a reward or compensation,
set it aside facedown and gain another in the same way. Then, the set-aside card is discarded or returned to the other player, as appropriate.

powerBody.value: You have the power of Idealism.
Once per encounter, when you add any cards to your hand, you

this power to place any of those cards facedown on this sheet in a reject pile. You may also use this power when you are dealt a starting hand.

When another power would take cards from your hand at random, you

this power to force that player to take some or all of them at random from your reject pile instead.

You may offer cards from your reject pile as part of a deal. If any player cannot draw cards because a deck and its discard pile are empty, discard your reject pile and any number of cards from your hand.

powerName.value: You have the power of Idealism.

superBody.value: When you use your power to place cards on this sheet,
gain cards from the same source equal to the number of cards that you placed. You may use your power on these cards as well, but if you do, do not resolve this effect for those placed cards.

history.value: A civilization that glorifies inflicting pain in excessively brutal rituals, the Sadists barely managed to survive to their space-faring age. Desiring to spread their unique form of worship across the many realms of space and time, these beings enter the Cosmos with an eager eye for torment and a mind full of cruel creativity.

wildBody.value: As a main player, after winning the encounter, for each player that was on the opposing side,
draw one card from the deck.

history.value: As the Schizoids slip between cascading alternative spacetimes, their mere presence shifts the reality of other creatures around them.

body.value: After you fail to make a deal, if you have at least four foreign colonies, you win the game!
After you draw a new hand, if you have at least three foreign colonies, you win the game!
After you make a deal, if you have at least three foreign colonies, you win the game!
If three of your foreign colonies each have at least four ships, you win the game!
If you have at least three foreign colonies in the same system, you win the game!
If you have at least five foreign colonies and at least three home colonies, you win the game!
If you have foreign colonies in at least three different systems and have three or fewer home colonies, you win the game! This condition cannot be chosen in a three player game.
After you re-establish a home colony, if you have at least two foreign colonies, you win the game!

powerBody.value: You have the power to Shift Reality.

As a main player, after you lose an encounter or fail to make a deal, the opposing main player draws a card at random from your condition deck and places it faceup on this sheet.

When any player(s) would win by the normal (not alternate) victory conditions,

history.value: For countless eons, the Void conflated abiogenesis and spontaneous generation so they are deeply offended at the notion that aliens exists. Although only some Void even tolerate the belief that there is life, those that do seek to cleanse the heavens of all beings, coporeal or otherwise.

wildBody.value: end one of your ships not in the encounter to the warp to cancel an artifact card. This is not treated as a card zap. The artifact card is discarded.

powerBody.value: You have the power to Absorb.

this power. All ships that would be sent to the warp during resolution are captured and placed on this sheet instead.

You may send a player's ships from this sheet to the warp as part of a deal.

If this sheet is turned facedown, all ships on it remain. If this sheet is removed from the game, send all ships on it to the warp.

short.value: Ships Never Stay in the Warp

history.value: Gooey entities from cold and dreary worlds, Zombies had tapped all sources of energy from their original home planets. They continued only by carefully recycling their own kind. "Living" on decomposing matter, they detest the unnecessary wastes of war and have developed morally dubious methods to ensure their numbers will never permanently be reduced.

wildBody.value: As part of a deal, you may free any number of your opponent's ships from the warp.

powerBody.value: You have the power of Reanimation.

this power to free all of your ships in the warp, sending them to one  of your home planets (including a planet without a home colony.)  Additionallly, you may free any number of another player's ships from the warp as part of a deal with that player.

powerName.value: You have the power of Reanimation.

superBody.value: After a player agrees to ally with you, instead of sending ships from their colonies,
send any number of their ships from the warp. This can allow them to be above their normal ship limit.
